[[File:Pekka Airaksinen.jpg|thumb|Pekka Airaksinen]] '''Pekka Airaksinen''' (21 August 1945 – 6 May 2019) was a [[Finland|Finnish]] composer of [[electronic music]].
Airaksinen formed his first band, [[The Sperm (band)|The Sperm]], in the 1960s. The Sperm mixed elements of [[avant-garde music]] with [[free jazz]] and [[psychedelic pop]]. Their concerts featured confrontational [[performance art]], which resulted in two members being arrested for simulating sexual intercourse and screening [[pornography|pornographic]] films.
Following The Sperm's breakup in the early 1970s, Airaksinen turned to [[Buddhism]] and ceased making music. He returned to music in the mid 1980s with his album ''Buddhas of Golden Light'', which mixed free jazz with percussion from a [[Roland 808]] drum machine.
In the 1990s, Airaksinen founded the Dharmakustannus label, on which he released numerous CDs and CD-Rs. The music styles of these releases varies considerable, ranging from [[new age]], [[ambient music|ambient]], [[house music|house]], [[jazz]] and [[improvised music|improvisation]].
Pekka Airaksinen died on 6 May 2019, at the age of 73.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.thewire.co.uk/news/54929/pekka-airaksinen-has-died|title=Pekka Airaksinen has died - The Wire|website=The Wire Magazine - Adventures In Modern Music|language=en|access-date=2019-05-08}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.rumba.fi/uutiset/elektronisen-musiikin-saveltaja-ja-muusikko-pekka-airaksinen-on-kuollut/|title=Elektronisen musiikin säveltäjä ja muusikko Pekka Airaksinen on kuollut|last=Fräntilä|first=Jarkko|website=Rumba.fi|language=fi|access-date=2019-05-08}}</ref>
